question: Who suggested that injecting bleach could cure you from COVID?
answer1: Donald Trump, former US president
answer3: No one, or maybe in your dreams someone did
message:
As crazy as it may sound, Donald Trump, former US president and liar extraordinaire, didn't encourage people to inject bleach in order to cure them from COVID.

After assuredly rambling about "light", "injection" and "COVID" in his usual word-salad-stream-of-consciousness style, he clarified: "It wouldn’t be through injections, almost a cleaning and sterilization of an area. Maybe it works, maybe it doesn’t work, but it certainly has a big effect if it’s on a stationary object.".

So feel free to tell your drunk-Trump-loving uncle to stop with the bullshit and shut up, for once.

question: Who claims sheep can self-medicate?
answer1: Jane Goodall, English primatologist and anthropologist
answer3: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, animal rights NGO
message:
When it comes to compiling info on animal research, PETA is the beeeest.

"An experiment found that sheep can acquire knowledge about food based on different tastes. When the animals are sick, they could use this knowledge to treat themselves by choosing plants with healing properties based on taste."

Can't wait for the next season of Shaun, M.D. to drop.

question: Who claims airplanes are used to spray chemical agents for pest control?
answer1: Conspiracy Theorists
answer3: No one, or maybe you overheard it on the bus
message: And it's actually true. How can this be? Are the authors of this game conspiracy theorists themselves? Hear us out: Often, pesticides are sprayed from airplanes over plantations. These are special airplanes for agricultural use, not to be confused with passenger and cargo airlines.

question: Who claims contrails left by airplanes are chemical agents sprayed for population control?
answer1: No one, or maybe Jaqen H'ghar did
message: Wake up, sheeple! The government tries to fool us... well, not in that way. This is a well-known conspiracy theory.

question: Who mused "turns out chemtrails are actually a message from time-traveling aliens describing the secret of teleportation"?
answer1: Neil deGrasse Tyson, astrophysicist
message:
In a message posted on X (former Twitter) on April Fools' Day 2017, Elon Musk referred to the popular and many times debunked conspiracy theory known as "chemtrails".

Partisans of this theory posit without proof that plumes left by aircrafts in the sky carry chemicals destined to various nefarious purposes, such as "sterilization, reduction of life expectancy, mind control or weather control".

Maybe it's just Elon smoking a blunt in the bathroom of his private jet, who knows?

question: Who said "I’m collecting horcruxes. I’m collecting infinity stones. Gandalf’s voice is in my head every time I put out a new one. For me, it is a movie now."?
answer1: The Artist Formerly Known as Prince, singer song-writer
message: In a 2023 interview with the Time, Taytay might have gone a bit too far to get her nerd creds despite Gandalf's voice repeatedly telling her that she "shall not pass".

question: Who theorized that "Losers don't matter in the history books."?
answer1: Vladimir Putin, president of Russia
answer2: Caesar, character of Fallout New Vegas
answer3: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, president of Turkey
message:
Caesar doesn't mince words regarding the demise of Mr. House in the video game Fallout: New Vegas.

You have to give it to Caesar: he's no-nonsense, no word salad.

question: Who asked "Can we get rid of all the Mexicans?"?
answer1: Mr. Garrison, South Park Elementary teacher
answer3: Jair Bolsonaro, former president of Brazil
message:
Mr. Garrison is a 4th-grade teacher at South Park Elementary School and a vocal racist.

He is also a character from the long-running show South Park, popular for its political and social satire.

Which doesn't make it okay, kids, mkay?

question: Who complained “I have five children. Four are men, and then in a moment of weakness the fifth came out a girl.”?
answer1: Jair Bolsonaro, former president of Brazil
answer2: Russell M. Nelson, president of a free church
message:
Provocative and unpredictable "strongman" Jair Bolsonaro admitting to a moment of weakness in public isn't what his fellows Brazilians were used to during his presidency.

They were definitely used to his derogatory comments on women and minorities, though.

But maybe this one time, he was just being sarcastic and not a sexist pig at all. Who knows.

question: Who warned "If you become a crocodile, it's your problem. If you become Superman, if some women grow beards or if a man starts talking in a high-pitched voice, (the laboratory) has nothing to do with that."?
answer1: Jair Bolsonaro, former president of Brazil
answer2: Eric Cartman, South Park Elementary student
answer3: Dr. Curtis Connors aka The Lizard, Spiderman foe
message:
Jair Bolsonaro held office as president of Brazil during the worldwide COVID-19 pandemic.

Here, speaking about his fantasies on the possible side effects of the vaccine, Bolsonaro was also not shy from sharing his outlandish and queerphobic theories with his nation and the world.

It's with crocodile tears that the Brazilian people sent him home after only one term.

question: Who said "Facts are stupid things"?
answer1: Ronald Reagan, former US president
message:
Actor turned US president Ronald Reagan had a slip of the tongue during his speech at the 1988 Republican National Convention.

He was, in fact, quoting the second president of the United States of America, John Adams, who said: "Facts are stubborn things", as Reagan clarified in a last-second save.

Facts are indeed stubborn and we like them even more when they're outlandishly stupid. So thanks to Mr. Reagan for forgetting his line in such a memorable way.

question: Who said "I think that gay marriage should be between a man and a woman."?
answer1: Arnold Schwarzenegger, former Governor of California
answer2: No one, or maybe in your dreams someone did
message:
Republican Arnold Schwarzenegger, August 27, 2003, in an interview on the Sean Hannity Show shortly after he announced he would run in the California gubernatorial recall race.

The Gubernator seemingly fell victim to Hannity's rapid-fire questions. Hasta la vista, baby!

question: Who said "Poor kids are just as bright as white kids"?
answer1: Joe Biden, US president
message:
Joseph Robinette Biden, Jr was speaking on education and the need to challenge students at a town hall hosted by the Asian & Latino Coalition in Des Moines when he made the remark, and then quickly sought to recover from it.

Joe is certainly giving grey hair to the White House's PR people with this one.

question: Who said "Strange women lying in ponds distributing swords is no basis for a system of government."?
answer1: Monty Python, gang of idiots
answer2: Boris Johnson, former UK Prime Minister
answer3: No one, or maybe you overheard it on the subway
message:
In a scene from Monty Python and the Holy Grail, King Arthur addresses some peasants as they ask him how one becomes a king.

He retells the legend of how the Lady of the Lake gifted him Excalibur, the sword that made him King, only to see his legitimacy being questioned by them.

Not-an-old-woman Dennis might have a point there.

question: Who said "There are a great many people in the country today, who through no fault of their own, are sane."?
answer1: Monty Python, also collectively known as the Pythons
answer2: Justin Trudeau, Prime Minister of Canada
message:
From Monty Python's TV show The Flying Circus, a sketch with a reverend who is vicar at St. Loony Up the Cream Bun and Jam.

Here is the full quote in its glorious absurdity: "There are a great many people in the country today, who through no fault of their own, are sane. Some of them were born sane, while others became sane later in their lives. It is up to people like you and me, who are out of our tiny little minds, to help them overcome their sanity.

question: Who explained that "The yes needs the no to win against the no."?
answer1: Monty Python, also collectively known as the Pythons
message:
You may not know Jean-Pierre Raffarin if you're not French, but he really made a splash with this short tirade when trying to weigh in favor of the European Constitution referendum – and not Raffarin-dum, we see you, pun lovers.

Anyways, was he trying to audition for the Pythons? We may never know, but one thing for sure is that he went viral before social media with this one.

question: Who said "There is only one bad word: taxes."?
answer1: Ron Swanson, Character in Parks and Recreation
message:
Ron Swanson is a character from the show "Parks and Recreation"; he works for the government department but detests everything the government tries to do.

In an effort to mold the minds of young Pawnee residents, Ron Swanson presents his elaborate Swanson pyramid of greatness, a diagram transcribing a very Swanson, if not outlandish, view of the world.

question: Who said "America: The only country that matters. If you want to experience other ‘cultures,’ use an atlas or a ham radio."?
answer1: Ron Swanson, Character in Parks and Recreation
answer3: No one, or maybe you overheard it on the train
message:
Ron Swanson is a character from the show "Parks and Recreation"; he works for the government department but detests everything the government tries to do.

In an effort to mold the minds of young Pawnee residents, Ron Swanson presents his elaborate Swanson pyramid of greatness, a diagram transcribing a very Swanson, if not outlandish, view of the world.

question:
Who said bananas are radioactive?
After all, we all know radiation is yellow!
answer1: Science
message: Bananas are a radioactive snack! Who needs a Geiger counter when you can just munch on potassium-packed produce? Well, the radioactivity is actually extremely low and not harmful to humans.

question: Who claims tinfoil can prevent the government from reading your passport?
answer1: Conspiracy Theorists
message: What's this all about? There are RFID chips in our passports and tinfoil might prevent machines from reading it... or not. Research is not quite sure of it. The thing is, they can only be read within a few centimeters, so nothing to worry about.
